Rationale
new module organiser, Dr Raheela Awais
Blurb
Overview
The School offers a range of projects that allow students to conduct research individually at Masters level under the supervision of a member of academic staff. Topics are closely allied to the research field of the supervisor, and the basis of the project may involve data collection by observation and experimentation in situ (field projects), in vitro (laboratory projects), or in silico (bioinformatics). However, all types of projects have the same learning outcomes (that is, all students should acquire the same kinds of skills; see below), achieved by in-depth study.  ​The nature of the lab or field-based projects might be adapted if the field trips or labs access are limited due to unavoidable circumstances
Educational Aims
To provide students with an in-depth understanding of an area of contemporary biological research.

To develop students' ability to design experiments to investigate hypotheses, to analyse data, and to critically interpret results cognisant of the relevant literature

To develop in students the confidence to work independently and in a team to effectively attain a scientific goal;

To develop students' ability to communicate scientific concepts and findings in a variety of formats.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The School offers a range of projects that allow students to conduct research individually at Masters level under the supervision of a member of academic staff. Topics are closely allied to the research field of the supervisor, and the basis of the project may involve data collection by observation and experimentation in situ (field projects), in vitro (laboratory projects), or in silico (bioinformatics). However, all types of projects have the same learning outcomes (that is, all students should acquire the same kinds of skills; see below), achieved by in-depth study.  ​The nature of the lab or field-based projects might be adapted if the field trips or labs access are limited due to unavoidable circumstances.
Outline Syllabus
Students indicate preferences from lists of projects and supervisors in relevant cognate areas. The exact nature and format of project and the timing of its elements may vary (as described in the module handbook), but all projects are designed to meet the same set of learning outcomes. Examples include: cancer biology, evolution and behaviour, biotechnology.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1: Asynchronous lecture recording to introduce the module and assessments; Teaching Method 2: synchronous online or F2F interactive workshops which include journal clubs, group work/discussions on critical thinking, reading and writing using sample grant proposals and published articles, group work/discussions on widely used advanced laboratory techniques. Teaching method 3: Project working time (lab, field, computer, etc) Teaching Method 4: Regular meetings with supervisors; Self -directed learning:These hours refer to time students spend working on their own, for example reading activity, helping with the understanding of their work in context to their research project and associated assessments.
All the lectures (for introducing the module and its assessment) are delivered asynchronously, and followed by F2F interactive workshops. Although the usual research project types will provisionally be available (including laboratory projects or field projects), but their nature will be adapted if necessary as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Examples include students pooling data but writing up individually; students analysing pre-existing data to write their reports; students using small datasets as pilot data, and styling their reports more like project proposals. Students will be informed that plans for teaching will be subject to change according to circumstances. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1: Project Grant proposal, written in the form of a grant application to an external funding body.
Assessment 2: Interim research project report.
Assessment 3: Final Project report written in the format of a manuscript that could be submitted for publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal.
Assessment 4: Approach & Technique-Supervisors assessment of the student's work during the project.
All the assessments are coursework type, which the students work on during the academic year. The assessments timetable will be made available to the students at the start of academic year. 2-3 months gap is provided between each of the three assessments to give students enough time to plan and work through the assessments at an appropriate pace.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Notes
Changes have been made to the Module as follows
1) Removal of assessment - Review article:
Based on students feedback as being over-assessed, an assessment has been removed to reduce workload.
2) Splitting the current assessment 2 into two separate assessments-Interim report and Approach & Technique:
Due to the completely different nature of these two assessments in terms of marking, word count, resit options, time of assessment etc, the previous assessment 2 has been split into two separate assessments (2 and 4) to provide students with further clarification on the conditions for assessment. Please note this is not an addition to the assessments

This module is due to commence in September 2019

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Plan and execute a piece of scientific research in a responsible, safe, professional and ethical manner;
 LO2 Formulate a hypothesis and design a coherent and feasible experimental plan to test that hypothesis using scientific methods and resources;
 LO3 ​​Analyse and critically evaluate data, observations and draw valid conclusions;
 LO4 Appreciate the importance of maintaining clear, accurate and up to date records;
 LO5 ​ Evaluate own performance and working standards, and place their work in the context of the wider scientific community; ​
 LO6 Synthesise and interpret the relevant literature and communicate findings in a variety of formats (oral, written reports) to supervisor, research staff and peers.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 ​​Technical proficiency in experimental or observational methods relevant to the specific project
 S2 ​​Problem solving skills, numeracy, IT skills
 S3 ​​Communication skills, ethical awareness.
 S4 Team work and ​Organisational skills

Rationale
new module organiser, Dr Raheela Awais
Blurb
Overview
The School offers a range of projects that allow students to conduct research individually at Masters level under the supervision of a member of academic staff. Topics are closely allied to the research field of the supervisor, and the basis of the project may involve data collection by observation and experimentation in situ (field projects), in vitro (laboratory projects), or in silico (bioinformatics). However, all types of projects have the same learning outcomes (that is, all students should acquire the same kinds of skills; see below), achieved by in-depth study.  ​The nature of the lab or field-based projects might be adapted if the field trips or labs access are limited due to unavoidable circumstances
Educational Aims
To provide students with an in-depth understanding of an area of contemporary biological research.

To develop students' ability to design experiments to investigate hypotheses, to analyse data, and to critically interpret results cognisant of the relevant literature

To develop in students the confidence to work independently and in a team to effectively attain a scientific goal;

To develop students' ability to communicate scientific concepts and findings in a variety of formats.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The School offers a range of projects that allow students to conduct research individually at Masters level under the supervision of a member of academic staff. Topics are closely allied to the research field of the supervisor, and the basis of the project may involve data collection by observation and experimentation in situ (field projects), in vitro (laboratory projects), or in silico (bioinformatics). However, all types of projects have the same learning outcomes (that is, all students should acquire the same kinds of skills; see below), achieved by in-depth study.  ​The nature of the lab or field-based projects might be adapted if the field trips or labs access are limited due to unavoidable circumstances.
Outline Syllabus
Students indicate preferences from lists of projects and supervisors in relevant cognate areas. The exact nature and format of project and the timing of its elements may vary (as described in the module handbook), but all projects are designed to meet the same set of learning outcomes. Examples include: cancer biology, evolution and behaviour, biotechnology.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1: Asynchronous lecture recording to introduce the module and assessments; Teaching Method 2: synchronous online or F2F interactive workshops which include journal clubs, group work/discussions on critical thinking, reading and writing using sample grant proposals and published articles, group work/discussions on widely used advanced laboratory techniques. Teaching method 3: Project working time (lab, field, computer, etc) Teaching Method 4: Regular meetings with supervisors; Self -directed learning:These hours refer to time students spend working on their own, for example reading activity, helping with the understanding of their work in context to their research project and associated assessments.
All the lectures (for introducing the module and its assessment) are delivered asynchronously, and followed by F2F interactive workshops. Although the usual research project types will provisionally be available (including laboratory projects or field projects), but their nature will be adapted if necessary as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Examples include students pooling data but writing up individually; students analysing pre-existing data to write their reports; students using small datasets as pilot data, and styling their reports more like project proposals. Students will be informed that plans for teaching will be subject to change according to circumstances. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1: Project Grant proposal, written in the form of a grant application to an external funding body.
Assessment 2: Interim research project report.
Assessment 3: Final Project report written in the format of a manuscript that could be submitted for publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal.
Assessment 4: Approach & Technique-Supervisors assessment of the student's work during the project.
All the assessments are coursework type, which the students work on during the academic year. The assessments timetable will be made available to the students at the start of academic year. 2-3 months gap is provided between each of the three assessments to give students enough time to plan and work through the assessments at an appropriate pace.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Notes
Changes have been made to the Module as follows
1) Removal of assessment - Review article:
Based on students feedback as being over-assessed, an assessment has been removed to reduce workload.
2) Splitting the current assessment 2 into two separate assessments-Interim report and Approach & Technique:
Due to the completely different nature of these two assessments in terms of marking, word count, resit options, time of assessment etc, the previous assessment 2 has been split into two separate assessments (2 and 4) to provide students with further clarification on the conditions for assessment. Please note this is not an addition to the assessments

This module is due to commence in September 2019

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Plan and execute a piece of scientific research in a responsible, safe, professional and ethical manner;
 LO2 Formulate a hypothesis and design a coherent and feasible experimental plan to test that hypothesis using scientific methods and resources;
 LO3 ​​Analyse and critically evaluate data, observations and draw valid conclusions;
 LO4 Appreciate the importance of maintaining clear, accurate and up to date records;
 LO5 ​ Evaluate own performance and working standards, and place their work in the context of the wider scientific community; ​
 LO6 Synthesise and interpret the relevant literature and communicate findings in a variety of formats (oral, written reports) to supervisor, research staff and peers.
Skills
 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 ​​Technical proficiency in experimental or observational methods relevant to the specific project
 S2 ​​Problem solving skills, numeracy, IT skills
 S3 ​​Communication skills, ethical awareness.
 S4 Team work and ​Organisational skills
